markdown: Pfizer Pharmaceuticals Group APPENDIX B: Diagnostic Worksheet for Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy: A. NEUROLOGICAL HISTORY Your standard neurological history should be performed. This history should include an inquiry into possible exposure to neurotoxic drugs or chemicals, and a family history of neurologic disease, weakness, or arthritis and joint deformities. Also make specific and detailed inquiry about symptoms of sensory, motor, and autonomic dysfunction. 1. Based on your history, does the patient have: option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] a) A condition other than diabetes which could cause neuropathy? option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] b) Exposure to known neurotoxins? option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] c) A family history of neuromuscular disorders? If Yes to any of the above, reconsider the diagnosis of diabetic peripheral neuropathy. Patient is not allowed to enter study if there is doubt about the diagnosis or a concomitant condition is present which could confuse the assessment of pain due to diabetic peripheral neuropathy. 2. Are any of the following sensory symptoms present in the hands or feet? a) Numbness option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] b) Dysesthesias, paresthesias option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] c) Allodynia option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] d) Burning/aching stabbing pain option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] Note: If symptoms present in hands only, consider alternative diagnosis! 3. Are any of the following motor symptoms present? a) Ankle weakness option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] b) Cramps option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] 4. Are any of the following autonomic symptoms present? Postural Hypotension a) Weakness on standing relieved by lying down option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] b) Fainting on standing relieved by lying down option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] Gastroparesis c) Dysphagia (difficulty in swallowing) option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] d) Anorexia option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] e) Nausea option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] f) Vomiting option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] g) Vague fullness after meal option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] Diabetic Diarrhea h) Nocturnal diarrhea option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] i) Fecal incontinence option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] j) More than 20 bowel movements/day option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] Colonic Atony k) Less than 2 bowel movements/week option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] l) Less than 1 bowel movement/3 days option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] --- Protocol ID A945-1008 40 Working Protocol inc. Amendment #2: August 7, 2002 CONFIDENTIAL Pfizer_MPatel_0203749 Source: https://www.industrydocuments.ucsf.edu/docs/lpjm0223

chunks.markdown: APPENDIX B: Diagnostic Worksheet for Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy:

A. NEUROLOGICAL HISTORY Your standard neurological history should be performed. This history should include an inquiry into possible exposure to neurotoxic drugs or chemicals, and a family history of neurologic disease, weakness, or arthritis and joint deformities. Also make specific and detailed inquiry about symptoms of sensory, motor, and autonomic dysfunction. 1. Based on your history, does the patient have: option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] a) A condition other than diabetes which could cause neuropathy? option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] b) Exposure to known neurotoxins? option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] c) A family history of neuromuscular disorders? If Yes to any of the above, reconsider the diagnosis of diabetic peripheral neuropathy. Patient is not allowed to enter study if there is doubt about the diagnosis or a concomitant condition is present which could confuse the assessment of pain due to diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

2. Are any of the following sensory symptoms present in the hands or feet? a) Numbness option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] b) Dysesthesias, paresthesias option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] c) Allodynia option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] d) Burning/aching stabbing pain option No: [ ] option Both Hands and Feet: [ ] option Feet Only: [ ] option Hands Only: [ ] Note: If symptoms present in hands only, consider alternative diagnosis! 3. Are any of the following motor symptoms present? a) Ankle weakness option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] b) Cramps option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] 4. Are any of the following autonomic symptoms present? Postural Hypotension a) Weakness on standing relieved by lying down option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] b) Fainting on standing relieved by lying down option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] Gastroparesis c) Dysphagia (difficulty in swallowing) option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] d) Anorexia option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] e) Nausea option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] f) Vomiting option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] g) Vague fullness after meal option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] Diabetic Diarrhea h) Nocturnal diarrhea option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] i) Fecal incontinence option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] j) More than 20 bowel movements/day option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] Colonic Atony k) Less than 2 bowel movements/week option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ] l) Less than 1 bowel movement/3 days option No: [ ] option Yes: [ ]
